Es un poquito anterior a Erauso y en su proceso inquisitorial de 1588, todas las autoridades presentes en ese proceso están obsesionadas con explorar su cuerpo, diseccionarlo y clasificarlo de manera muy violenta. Cuando Heleno de Céspedes en el juicio le preguntan por qué siendo mujer principalmente, y habiendo parido, se casó con otra mujer como ella, si tiene esto por lícito casarse dos mujeres, Céspedes contestó con que se casó por entender que era hombre y no mujer y que podía lícitamente, siendo hombre, casarse con mujer, que bien sabe que dos mujeres no pueden casarse. Y así no lo hizo por burra del sacramento antes, lo hizo por estar en servicio de Dios. Me encanta esta respuesta siempre. Y añadió Céspedes en el proceso añadió que en realidad de verdad es y fue hermafrodito, que ha tenido y tiene dos naturas, una de hombre y otra de mujeres, y que lo que en esto pasa es que cuando parió, con la fuerza que puso en el parto, se le rompió un pellejo que tenía sobre el caño de la orina y salió una cabeza como medio dedo pulgar, que pareció en su hechura miembro de hombre y que cuando tenía deseo y alteración natural se salía, como dicho tiene. If Erauso's crossdressing is understood at the time by the political and ecclesiastical authorities of the 17th century as an ascent towards masculine virtue and all the transforming power of the clothes and the performance of masculinity manage to operate successfully in Catalina de Arauso, it is largely because of her lineage, because of all this ancestry of Lola, her aunt Ursula, her military father and all, since that helps, of course, to catapult her in front of Erauso. Céspedes was the daughter of an enslaved mulatto woman and she does not manage to survive the slashing glances that surround her body. She is a little before Erauso and in her inquisitorial process of 1588, all the authorities present in that process are obsessed with exploring her body, dissecting it and classifying it in a very violent way. When Heleno de Cespedes was asked during the trial why, being mainly a woman, and having given birth, he married another woman like her, if it was licit to marry two women, Cespedes answered that he married because he understood that he was a man and not a woman and that he could licitly, being a man, marry a woman, as he well knew that two women could not marry. In any case, I think we can stay with words that I was going to say are by Erauso, but since almost none of them are actually by Erauso, this one is certainly not. Nor do we know if Montalbán wrote it at all for sure, but let's imagine that he did. In the nun ensign of Montalbán the character says what is it that he has to see me? Am I some monster he has never seen? Or the beast they invented that with letters and weapons was seen in the Polish kingdom has not seen a man without a beard? That gives me a lot of tenderness because I imagine when I imagine Brauso, already fed up with Europe, saying that this is how far we have come, this is how far we have come with this circus of the nun Alfered and saying I leave all this hybrid, monstrous creature that you have created for your myths and I am going to be Antonio, I am going.

utterances.speaker: B
utterances.text: A ser mercader y muletero.
utterances.text_en: To be a merchant and muleteer.

utterances.speaker: A
utterances.text: Voy a ser muletero y punto.
utterances.text_en: I'm going to be a muleteer, period.

utterances.speaker: B
utterances.text: Bueno, amigas, nos caía fatal la monja alférez. Esperamos que a vosotras un poquito mejor. Y si os cae mal ella, que no os cargamos mal vosotras. Eso os pedimos.
utterances.text_en: Well, my friends, we disliked the ensign nun. We hope you like her a little better. And if you don't like her, we hope you don't dislike her. That's what we ask of you.

utterances.speaker: A
utterances.text: Otras no.
utterances.text_en: Others do not.

utterances.speaker: B
utterances.text: Hasta dentro de dos semanas.
utterances.text_en: See you in two weeks.
